docs.lead_paragraph: As he struggled to come to terms with the 1994 Republican sweep of Congress, President Clinton made one point to anyone who would listen: he had lost the fight to overhaul health care, the centerpiece of his agenda, because his opponents went on television and defined his program. He would never let it happen again.

headline.main: Stung by Defeats in '94, Clinton Regrouped and Co-opted G.O.P. Strategies
headline.kicker: THE 1996 ELECTIONS: THE PRESIDENCY -- THE STRATEGY

docs.abstract: President Clinton, as he struggled to come to terms with 1994 Republican sweep of Congress, began working with his staff on strategy to reshape his image and form campaign that labeled Congress as enemy; mistakes made by Republican strategists concerning several proposed legislation packages and budget remedies discussed (M)
docs.snippet: As he struggled to come to terms with the 1994 Republican sweep of Congress, President Clinton made one point to anyone who would listen: he had lost the fight to overhaul health care, the centerpiece of his agenda, because his opponents went on...

docs.lead_paragraph: NEW YORK Carolyn McCarthy Democrat, 52, Fourth District. A former nurse, Mrs. McCarthy became a gun-control advocate after a gunman killed her husband on the Long Island Rail Road in 1993 and wounded her son. Decided to run for Congress when her Representative, Daniel Frisa, a Republican, voted to repeal an assault-weapons ban. Supports abortion rights and, while she says she personally opposes the death penalty, would not support its repeal because of her district's backing of it. Her traditionally Republican district covers western Nassau County.
docs.abstract: New faces in Congress include Democrat Carolyn McCarthy (NY), Democrat James H Maloney (Conn), Democrat William J Pascrell Jr (NJ), Democrat Steven R Rothman (NJ) and Republican Mike Pappas (NJ) (M)
docs.snippet: NEW YORK     Carolyn McCarthy    Democrat, 52, Fourth District. A former nurse, Mrs. McCarthy became a gun-control advocate after a gunman killed her husband on the Long Island Rail Road in 1993 and wounded her son. Decided to run for Congress when...

docs.lead_paragraph: Natalie Smith of Pittsburgh says she likes her new 1996 Mazda Protege, but she worries about its air bag. The bag was designed to protect the average man, about 165 pounds and 5 foot 9 -- about 55 pounds heavier and 7 inches taller than Ms. Smith, and according to Government statistics, 19 ''short statured'' people, most of whom were not wearing seat belts, have been killed by air bags in crashes that they otherwise could have survived. So she asked her dealer to disconnect the bag, but was told that it would be illegal for him to do so.

headline.main: The Dangers From Air Bags And Ways to Avoid Them

docs.abstract: Air bags, automotive safety device designed to protect average man, pose safety risk to short adults and children; advice on minimizing risk (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: FLORIDA Jim Davis Democrat, 39. A lawyer, Mr. Davis has served in the Florida House since 1988 and is currently the majority leader. His campaign strategy included emphasizing local issues and his moderate stance and assuring voters that if elected, he would not become a tool of Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House Democratic leader. Mr. Davis's rival for the open seat in Florida's 11th Congressional District was Mark Sharpe, a former Navy intelligence officer who brought in Speaker Newt Gingrich to help raise campaign money and said it was important for Republicans to keep control of Congress ''if only to prevent national health insurance.''
docs.abstract: Newly elected House members include: Democrat Jim Davis (Fla), Democrat Julia M Carson (Indiana), Republican Jim Ryun (Kansas), Republican Wes Watkins (Okla), Democrat David E Price (NC) and Democrat Dennis J Kucinich (Ohio); photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Pressing a new case for the equal treatment of same-sex couples, San Francisco is moving to become the first major city in the country to require the companies with which it does business to offer health and other benefits to the unmarried partners of their employees. The city's Board of Supervisors passed legislation by a 10-to-0 vote on Monday to prohibit the city government from contracting with companies that do not make the same benefits available to employees' domestic partners that they do to the married spouses of their workers. The measure will now go to the Mayor, Willie L. Brown Jr., has said he supports it in principle.

headline.main: San Francisco Nears Domestic-Partner Benefits Rule for Companies

docs.abstract: San Francisco is moving to become first major city in country to require companies with which it does business to offer health and other benefits to unmarried partners of their employees; Board of Supervisors passes, 10-0, legislation prohibiting city from contracting with companies that do not make same benefits available to employees' domestic partners that they do to married spouses of their workers (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Four years ago Bill Clinton won the Presidency with an outsized agenda and an underwhelming mandate, and the gulf between the two left him struggling in the first half of his term simply to establish his legitimacy. By the midpoint, the President had been reduced to proclaiming his own relevance. Last night Mr. Clinton won re-election with a larger margin but with a manifesto both smaller and less clear. And if the promise of achievement glistens, potential pitfalls abound, from the ancient feuds of Bosnia to the paper chase of special prosecutors at home.

headline.main: The Second Term: Promise and Peril
headline.kicker: THE 1996 ELECTIONS: THE PRESIDENCY -- LOOKING AHEAD

docs.abstract: Portent of Pres Clinton's re-election to second term remains unclear, as potential pitfalls abound, even though promise of achievement also glistens; Clinton has sounded less certain trumpet for second term, and his goals are far more modest; while juxtaposition of expansive impulses and accommodationist tactics has been hallmark of his career, his capacity for adjustment has helped repeatedly to turn weaknesses into strengths and setbacks into progress in perpetual campaign in which winning is all; for first time in his life, he will no longer be running for re-election, but instead for place in history; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Four years ago Bill Clinton won the Presidency with an outsized agenda and an underwhelming mandate, and the gulf between the two left him struggling in the first half of his term simply to establish his legitimacy. By the midpoint, the President had...

docs.lead_paragraph: When Leonard Garrambone became Nynex's head of purchasing two years ago, his assignment was clear: ride herd on the nonpayroll expenses, everything from furniture to health benefits to consulting. Nynex executives guessed they were spending $3 billion a year. But Mr. Garrambone wasn't satisfied with guesswork. After six months of sleuthing, he gave management the shocker: the actual number was $6 billion. ''People forget things like stationery or services,'' he said.

headline.main: The Downsizing Trend Shifts From Jobs to the Things That Companies Buy
headline.kicker: Taking Penny-Pinching to the Next Level

docs.abstract: Corporate America, after a decade of re-engineering and downsizing, much of it undertaken to reduce costs, has moved to new target: billions it spends on goods and services, especially as companies shift more tasks to outside suppliers; businesses are hiring new breed of purchasing professionals to tackle those expenses; well-paid specialists, many with graduate degrees, are replacing purchasing agents of old, who generally were high school graduates accustomed to being told what to buy and from whom to buy it; companies that have saved money by hiring purchasing professionals include Nynex, Thermo King division of Westinghouse Electric, Owens Corning, Riverwood International Corp, Electronic Data Systems Corp and Ford Motor Co; photo (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: As President Clinton won a second term tonight with surprising victories in former Republican strongholds like Florida and New Hampshire, Democratic candidates for governor also headed to victory in states well known for their Republican leanings. In Indiana, which Mr. Clinton failed to win for the second time, voters kept the governor's office Democratic. Lieut. Gov. Frank L. O'Bannon narrowly defeated Stephen Goldsmith, the Mayor of Indianapolis, who was widely perceived as a rising star in the national Republican Party.

headline.main: Democrats Make Inroads In Elections for Governor
headline.kicker: THE 1996 ELECTIONS: THE NATION -- THE GOVERNORS

docs.abstract: Gubernatorial election results; Democrats Thomas R Carper (Delaware), Frank L O'Bannon (Indiana), Mel Carnahan (Missouri), Jeanne Shaheen (New Hampshire), James B Hunt Jr (NC) and Howard Dean (Vermont) win; Republicans Michael O Leavitt (Utah) Edward T Schafer (N Dak) and Cecil H Underwood (W Va) win (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: LAWSUITS over two eventually fatal cases of cervical cancer that were missed in repeated misreadings of Pap smears and news reports of substandard methods in some laboratories have had at least two happy results. The attention of women and the medical profession is now focused on the true benefits and limitations of this most popular screening tool. And new rules have been established and techniques designed to improve the test's accuracy. One technique, Papnet, uses a computer to search for abnormalities in smears deemed ''normal'' by laboratory technicians. Its manufacturer, Neuromedical Systems Inc., has raised professional hackles with aggressive advertising urging women to pay the $40 themselves if their insurance companies refuse to cover the extra cost.
docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health article on Pap smears for detecting cervical cancer; discusses benefits and shortcomings of screening tool and efforts to improve test (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Shards from a broken campaign: No matter who wins the Presidency on Tuesday, no matter who gains or loses control of Congress, the returns, like the conduct of candidates great and small these many months, will confirm the nation's drift to the right.

headline.main: Nation Is Still Locked Onto Rightward Path, Leaving Liberals Beside Road

docs.abstract: R W Apple analysis contends that no matter who wins Presidency, no matter who gains or loses control of Congress, returns will confirm nation's drift to right; maintains that Pres Clinton is great exemple of this continuing trend; holds that Clinton, having stubbed his toe on liberal causes in first two years of his term, has espoused selected conservative causes (M)
